sentences.sentence: On the third day, when the parents and sisters had gone away, Cinderella went once more to her mother’s grave( 坟墓 ) and said to the little tree:
“Shiver( 颤抖 ) and quiver( 发抖 ), my little tree,
Silver and gold throw down over me.”
And now the birds threw down to her a dress which was more splendid( 华丽的 ) and magnificent( 极好的 ) than any she had yet had, and also a pair of( 一双 )  golden slippers( 鞋 ).
And when she went to the festival in the dress, everyone was speechless with astonishment( 惊异 ).
The King’s son danced with her only, and if any one invited her to dance, he said, “She is my partner( 舞伴 ).”
When evening came, Cinderella wished to leave, and the King’s son was anxious( 渴望的 ) to go with her,
but she escaped( 逃走 ) from him so quickly that he could not follow her.
But the King’s son had caused the whole staircase( 楼梯 ) to be smeared( 涂抹 ) with pitch( 沥青 ), and there, when she ran down, the girl’s left slipper stuck.
The King’s son picked it up( 捡起 ) , and it was small and dainty( 小巧精致的 ), and all golden.
Next morning, he went with it to the King, and said to him, “I will marry only the woman whose foot this golden slipper fits.”
Then the two sisters were glad, for they had pretty feet.
The eldest went with the shoe into her room and wanted to try it on, and her mother stood by.
But she could not get her big toe( 脚趾 ) into it, and the shoe was too small for her.
Then her mother gave her a knife and said, “Cut the toe off; when you are Queen you will have no need to walk anywhere.”
The sister cut the toe off, forced the foot into the shoe, tried to ignore( 忽略 ) the pain, and went out to the King’s son.
Then he took her on his horse as his bride( 新娘 ) and rode away with her.
But when they rode past Cinderella’s mother’s grave, there on the tree sat the two pigeons( 鸽子 ) and cried,
“Turn and look, turn and look,
There’s blood within the shoe,
The shoe is too small for her,
Your true bride waits for you.”
Then he looked at her foot and saw how the blood was streaming( 流出 ) from it.
He turned his horse round and took the false( 假的 ) bride home again, and said she was not the true one, and that the other sister was to put the shoe on.
Then this one went into her room and got her toes safely into the shoe, but her heel( 脚跟 ) was too large.
So her mother gave her a knife and said, “Cut a bit off your heel; when you are Queen you will have no need to walk anywhere.”
The sister cut off a bit of her heel, forced her foot into the shoe, tried to ignore the pain, and went out to the King’s son.
He took her on his horse as his bride, and rode away with her, but when they passed by the tree, two little pigeons sat on it and cried,
“Turn and look, turn and look,
There’s blood within the shoe,
The shoe is too small for her,
Your true bride waits for you.”
He looked down at her foot and saw how the blood was running out of her shoe, and how it had stained( 染污 ) her white stocking( 长筒袜 ).
Then he turned his horse and took the false bride home again.
“This also is not the right one,” said he.
“Do you have another daughter?”
“No,” said the man.
“There is the dirty little kitchen girl whom my late( 已故的 ) wife left behind( 遗留下 )  her, but she cannot possibly be your bride.”
The King’s son said he was to send her up to him; but the mother answered, “Oh, no, she is much too dirty, she cannot show herself!”
But the King’s son absolutely( 极其 ) insisted( 坚持 ) on it, and Cinderella had to be called.
She first washed her hands and face clean, and then went and bowed( 鞠躬 ) down before the King’s son, who gave her the golden slipper.
Then she seated herself on a stool( 凳子 ), drew her foot out of the heavy wooden shoe, and put it into the slipper, which fitted like a glove( 正合适 ).
And when she rose up and the King’s son looked at her face he recognized( 认出 ) the beautiful girl who had danced with him and cried, “That is the true bride!”
The step-mother and the two sisters were terrified( 害怕的 ) and became pale with rage( 愤怒 );
he, however, took Cinderella on his horse and rode away with her.
As they passed by the tree, the two white doves( 鸽子 ) cried:
“Turn and look, turn and look,
No blood is in the shoe,
The shoe is not too small for her,
Your true bride rides with you.”
And then the doves came flying down and settled( 降落 ) on Cinderella’s shoulders, one on the right, the other on the left, and remained sitting there.
When the wedding( 婚礼 ) with the King’s son had to be celebrated, the two false( 虚情假意的 ) sisters came and wanted to get into favor with Cinderella and share her good fortune( 运气 ).
When the betrothed( 订了婚的 ) couple went to the church, the elder was at the right side and the younger at the left, and the pigeons pecked( 啄 ) out one eye of each of them.
Afterwards( 之后 ) as they came back, the elder was at the left, and the younger at the right, and then the pigeons pecked out the other eye of each.
And thus, for their wickedness( 恶毒 ) and falsehood( 虚伪 ), they were punished with blindness as long as they lived.
